newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan lags in opening construction market - U.S..
newsitem.headline: Japan lags in opening construction market - U.S..

text.p: Japan will open bidding for a new international airport to foreign firms but still lags on opening its construction market, a senior U.S. trade official said on Thursday.

Deputy U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Japan Marjory Searing told reporters that bidding for the 3.6 trillion yen ($29 billion) Chubu International Airport, slated to begin construction by 2000 near Nagoya in central Japan, would be opened up to foreign firms.
"Japan decided voluntarily to ease the procedures for this particular project beginning April 1," she said.
However the so-called Japan Action Plan, launched in 1994 and aimed at opening the Japanese construction market to foreign firms, has yet to show satisfactory results, Searing said.
"We are very dissatisfied... Since the Action Plan came into effect the number of foreign firms in construction has dropped considerably," she said.
A major obstacle to foreign construction firms was finding Japanese joint venture partners, she added.
"Under the Action Plan foreign firms are finding it very difficult to find Japanese companies willing to enter into a joint venture with them," she said.

Searing said there had been some progress on opening the medical care market but said there had been delays in registration of imported medical equipment and criticised what she called inefficiencies in the Japanese health-care system.
"Delays in the registration of high-tech imported medical equipment are not in the interests of the Japanese patient," she said.

Asked if the U.S. Federal Communications Commission would soon grant a licence to the U.S. subsidiary of Japanese telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. (NTT) to run telecommunications services based in the United States, Searing said the process may be drawn out.
"It's very hard for the U.S. to continue to open its markets further to outsiders when we face resistance from some countries to do the same," she said. ($1=124 yen)
